hints_html:
Making two clever observations makes this problem much more tractable. First notice that the right hand sides are all congruent to \(\displaystyle -1\) modulo the numbers on the far right.

The other observation is that the three moduli on the right are three consecutive pairwise coprime numbers so the Chinese Remainder Theorem will help finish the problem.

Making two clever observations makes this problem much more tractable. First notice that the right hand sides are all congruent to <math> \displaystyle -1 </math> modulo the numbers on the far right.
The other observation is that the three moduli on the right are three consecutive pairwise coprime numbers so the Chinese Remainder Theorem will help finish the problem.
question: 3 (b)
sols_html:
Proceeding as in the hints yields

\[\begin{aligned} x &\equiv -1 \mod{999}\\ x &\equiv -1 \mod{1000}\\ x &\equiv -1 \mod{1001}\end{aligned}\]

As

\[\begin{aligned} 999 &= 3^{3} \cdot 37\\ 1000 &= 2^{3} \cdot 5^{3}\\ 1001 &= 7 \cdot 11 \cdot 13\end{aligned}\]

we see that all these moduli are coprime. Hence by the Chinese remainder theorem, we have that a unique solution is given by

\(\displaystyle x \equiv -1 \mod {999 \cdot 1000 \cdot 1001}\)

or expanded and made positive

\(\displaystyle x \equiv 999998999 \mod {999999000}\)

statement_html:
Find the least nonnegative integer x that satisfies the following system of linear congruences.

\[\begin{aligned} x &\equiv 998 \mod{999}\\ x &\equiv 999 \mod{1000}\\ x &\equiv 1000 \mod{1001}\end{aligned}\]
